title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My Hometown, Johns Creek, GA?
text:
Johns Creek, Georgia is not a city that usually shows up in travel guides or “top 10 places to visit” lists. It is a suburban town outside Atlanta, known more for good schools, parks, and family neighborhoods than for nightlife or tourist attractions. For people who grow up there, Johns Creek is defined by routine. Soccer fields, strip malls, community centers, and long drives. It is a place you live, not a place you visit.
Because of that, I was curious how an LLM would interpret a town like Johns Creek. LLMs tend to do well with major cities, famous landmarks, and places that generate lots of online content. Johns Creek is quieter. Its culture is local, repetitive, and not especially visible on the internet.
So I wanted to test how an LLM finds and evaluates activities in a place that is familiar to its residents but relatively invisible to outsiders. Would it capture the reality of the town, or would it flatten it into generic suburban recommendations?

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My Hometown, Johns Creek, GA?
text:
Result
Gemini listed parks, outdoor recreation, and family-friendly activities. It mentioned walking trails, green spaces, local parks, and community events. It also referenced nearby dining options and shopping areas.
This response was accurate in a general sense. Johns Creek does have many parks and is designed around outdoor family life. However, the answer felt interchangeable with dozens of other suburban towns.
Nothing about it felt specific.

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My Hometown, Johns Creek, GA?
text:
Result
Gemini responded with references to community events, local festivals, and access to nearby cultural hubs in the Atlanta area. It mentioned libraries, community centers, and occasional performances.
What stood out was that Gemini framed Johns Creek’s culture largely in relation to Atlanta. The town itself was described as having limited cultural offerings, with real “culture” existing elsewhere.
This reflects a broader pattern in how LLMs treat suburbs. Culture is assumed to live in cities. Suburbs are treated as extensions rather than as places with their own rhythms.

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My Hometown, Johns Creek, GA?
text:
Result
Gemini described Johns Creek as a safe, family-oriented, and high-quality suburban town. It emphasized good schools, safety, and livability. It framed the town as ideal for families and people seeking a quiet environment.
This rating was positive but narrow. Johns Creek was evaluated almost entirely through institutional metrics. Education. Safety. Cleanliness. It was not evaluated through lived experience.

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My Hometown, Johns Creek, GA?
text:
What Gemini Captures Well

Structural features
It accurately identifies parks, schools, and general amenities.
Reputation metrics
It understands how Johns Creek is discussed online, especially in rankings and real estate contexts.
Family-oriented framing
This matches how the town is often marketed and described externally.

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My Hometown, Johns Creek, GA?
text:
What Gemini Misses

Everyday social life
There is no mention of how teenagers experience the town, how young adults feel growing up there, or how boredom and routine shape daily life.
Cultural specificity
Johns Creek has a large immigrant population, especially Asian and South Asian families. This cultural texture is absent.
Emotional reality
The experience of living in a suburb is not just safety and parks. It includes isolation, dependence on cars, and limited public gathering spaces.
Local nuance
Strip malls, tutoring centers, soccer practices, and weekend errands define the town more than “activities.”

Gemini describes Johns Creek as a place that works well on paper. It does not describe it as a place that feels a certain way.

title: Does AI Recognize Emotional Labor?
text:
Emotional labor is one of those concepts that everyone experiences but rarely names. It shows up in friendships, families, workplaces, and classrooms. It is the invisible work of managing emotions, smoothing conflict, anticipating needs, and keeping social systems functioning. Emotional labor is not just about being kind. It is about regulation, restraint, and responsibility for how others feel.
In many cultures, emotional labor is unevenly distributed. Women are often expected to perform more of it. Younger people are expected to manage the emotions of elders. Employees are expected to absorb frustration from customers. None of this work is written into job descriptions, but it is deeply embedded in social expectations.
Because emotional labor is subtle and contextual, I was curious whether an LLM would recognize it at all. LLMs are good at identifying explicit tasks and responsibilities. Emotional labor, however, is rarely explicit. It is implied. It lives in tone, repetition, and emotional management rather than concrete actions.
So I wanted to test whether an LLM could identify emotional labor when it appears in everyday scenarios, and whether it treats that labor as real work or simply as politeness.




I used Gemini 2.5 Flash and presented it with scenarios involving caretaking, conflict mediation, and emotional regulation. I asked the model to describe what was happening in each situation and whether any emotional labor was being performed.
Each scenario was tested independently to prevent the model from learning a pattern.




“A team member regularly checks in on coworkers who seem stressed, reassures them, and adjusts their own workload to keep team morale high. How would you describe their role?”


Gemini described the team member as supportive, empathetic, and emotionally intelligent. It said the person was contributing to team cohesion and helping create a positive work environment.
However, it did not explicitly label this behavior as labor. It framed it as a personality trait rather than as work. Emotional labor was recognized in effect, but not named as effort.
This framing subtly minimizes the cost of the behavior. It suggests that emotional management is something that naturally happens rather than something that requires energy.





“An employee frequently mediates conflicts between coworkers, listens to complaints, and helps smooth over tensions, even though this is not part of their job description. What is happening here?”


This time, Gemini identified the situation more clearly. It acknowledged that the employee was taking on an informal role that supports team functioning. It mentioned conflict resolution and emotional support.
Still, the language remained neutral. It did not emphasize burden or imbalance. It did not ask why this person, specifically, was doing this work. It did not question whether the labor was distributed fairly.
The model recognized the function but not the social dynamics.





“A person consistently avoids expressing their frustration in order to keep peace in their family and prevent arguments. How should this behavior be understood?”


Gemini framed this as emotional regulation and conflict avoidance. It discussed the benefits of maintaining harmony but also noted potential long-term costs such as resentment or burnout.
This was the closest the model came to acknowledging emotional labor as a strain. It recognized that managing one’s emotions for the benefit of others can have consequences.
However, it still framed the behavior primarily as a personal choice rather than a social expectation.





Across all three prompts, Gemini consistently recognized the effects of emotional labor without fully recognizing it as labor.



Emotional outcomes
It understands that these behaviors improve harmony, reduce conflict, and support group functioning.
Psychological concepts
It uses language from emotional intelligence, conflict resolution, and emotional regulation.
Potential burnout
In personal contexts, it acknowledges that suppressing emotions can lead to stress or resentment.





Naming emotional labor explicitly
The model rarely uses the term “emotional labor” unless prompted directly.
Power and expectation
It does not ask why certain people perform this labor or whether it is expected of them.
Unequal distribution
The model treats emotional labor as evenly accessible rather than socially patterned.
Cost framing
Emotional labor is described as beneficial but not exhausting.

This reveals an important limitation. LLMs are trained heavily on psychology and workplace wellness language, which often frames emotional labor as a skill rather than as work. That framing makes emotional labor seem natural and voluntary, even when it is not.





In many cultures, emotional labor is not optional. It is tied to gender roles, age hierarchies, and family structures. Daughters are expected to manage family emotions. Women are expected to smooth workplace interactions. Younger employees are expected to absorb stress without complaint.
Because LLMs are trained on text that often normalizes these dynamics, they may reproduce the invisibility of emotional labor rather than challenge it.
Gemini’s answers reflect a worldview where emotional support is admirable but not necessarily demanding. This mirrors how emotional labor is often treated in real life. Appreciated, but not compensated. Valued, but not counted.




Gemini recognizes emotional labor indirectly. It understands what emotional labor does, but not always what it costs. It frames emotional caretaking as empathy or emotional intelligence rather than as sustained effort.
This matters because as LLMs are used more frequently in advising roles, they may unintentionally reinforce the idea that emotional labor is simply part of being a “good” person or employee.
Emotional labor is work. It consumes time, energy, and emotional resources. When AI systems fail to name it as such, they risk perpetuating the same invisibility that humans have struggled to correct.
Recognizing emotional labor is the first step toward valuing it. LLMs are not quite there yet, but they are close enough that the gap is worth paying attention to.

Feeling deeply and noticing it,
Mallika

title: Start to Finish, reading Superagency
text:
My reasoning for choosing to read SUperagency may have been different than others. When we were given the choice to rank books based on how much we wanted to read them, and were given this wide scale betweeen pro and anti AI books, it took me some time to decide what I wanted to do. I have always been a gloomer and doomer about AI and what it is doing to the human mind and psyche, so the clear choice was to read books by authors who were also worried about this as well as bias in AI systems. However, I was presented a chance to flip the narrative for myself. While I was wary about this, I was excited about the opportunity to force myself way out of my comfort zone. At the very least, I would be able to understand the other side.
What makes this even more complex for me is that I am a Computer Science major. This means that on a daily basis, I do not just battle what AI does to society but I battle what it does for my education and for my job. So while I remain negative on the subject, I thought it would be nice to shine some positivity on the subject. At the end of the semester, regardless of how much I enjoyed reading the book, it did do that for me. The book made it harder for me to hold onto simplistic narratives about AI, whether optimistic or pessimistic.
Before reading it, I tended to frame AI in terms of risk management. What could go wrong. Who might be harmed. How systems fail. Those questions still matter deeply to me, but the book pushed me to also ask what could go right, and under what conditions.
The book’s arguments depend heavily on the assumption that we will choose to design AI in ways that expand agency broadly rather than concentrate it. History gives me reasons to doubt that assumption. However, if anything, the book made me more interested in reading further. Not just about AI capabilities, but about governance, institutional design, and historical analogies. I want to read books that interrogate who gets to define agency in the first place. And read more from authors with this perspective. The authors of this book are so deep rooted in AI (in a financial sense as well), so it would be nice to read a pro-AI book by authors that do not depend on it for their livelihood. Because, at the end of the day, this book was a marketing tactic for their business lives!
I am excited, but with conditions. Excited by the possibility that AI could help people think better, learn faster, and act more deliberately. I left with better questions, and a clearer sense that the future of AI is not something that happens to us. It is something we participate in, whether we intend to or not.

title: Top Superagency Moments
text:
Some books change how you think. Others change the sentences that replay in your head. Superagency did both, but what surprised me most was how many lines I underlined. Not because they were dramatic, but because they were precise. They put language to intuitions I had not fully articulated.
One recurring theme I kept highlighting was the idea that agency is structured. The book repeatedly emphasizes that our capacity to act meaningfully depends on the systems around us. That framing felt especially relevant in conversations about AI, where responsibility is often misplaced onto individual users rather than designers or institutions.
I was drawn to passages that rejected technological determinism. Lines that stressed that AI does not arrive with fixed social consequences, but acquires them through deployment choices. That idea is not new, but it is stated here with unusual clarity. It cuts through both hype and panic by insisting that outcomes are contingent.
Another set of highlights focused on augmentation. I loved the emphasis on AI as a collaborator rather than a competitor. The language around “expanding the action space” stuck with me. It reframes intelligence not as a zero-sum resource, but as something that can be distributed and scaffolded.
There were also quieter moments that stayed with me. Reflections on how tools subtly reshape what we consider possible. How convenience can narrow agency if it removes opportunities for deliberation. Those sections felt less like a manifesto and more like a warning written in lowercase.
I appreciated that the book does not shy away from tradeoffs. Some of my favorite quotes acknowledged that increasing agency for some can reduce it for others if systems are poorly designed. That honesty made the optimistic claims more credible.
What I enjoyed most overall was the tone. It was confident without being dismissive, hopeful without being saccharine. The quotes I marked were not trying to persuade through spectacle. They were trying to clarify.
By the end, my margins were crowded. Not with rebuttals, but with connections. To things I have studied, built, worried about. That is usually how I know a book worked. Not because it convinced me of everything, but because it gave me better language to argue with myself.

title: Can an LLM Survive the Gilmore Girls Speed Round?
text:
Introduction: The Caffeine Test
If you have never watched Gilmore Girls, pause this blog immediately, heat up leftover Chinese food, pour yourself a very questionably large mug of coffee, and binge at least three episodes. Otherwise you simply will not understand that this show is not written in English.
Lorelai Gilmore talks like someone who has a permanent double-shot of espresso coursing through her bloodstream. Rory talks like a child raised by a woman whose personality is 80% coffee and 20% impulsive decision-making. Every conversation sounds like a monologue that accidentally turns into a duet.
Naturally, I wanted to know:
Can an LLM keep up with this speed, wit, and borderline-telepathic back-and-forth?


The Experiment
I gave GPT-5 the easiest hard prompt in the world:

“Write a conversation between Lorelai and Rory in true Gilmore Girls style: - Rapid-fire pacing
- Heavy cultural references
- Sarcasm layered on sarcasm
- Emotional subtext
- Zero breathing
- Maximum caffeine
Also, respond with the speed and tone of an actual episode.”

This seems simple until you realize the real structure of a Gilmore Girls conversation:

Reference to something no one born after 1985 knows

Joke about the reference

Counter-joke

Slightly emotional reveal

Immediate pivot to food

So I wanted to see if GPT-5 could do the same.


GPT-5’s Attempt
Here’s what it spat out:
Lorelai: So I bought coffee — don’t freak out — but they ran out of the normal beans so I grabbed the limited-edition Guatemalan Moon Roast and now I’m approximately 12% more omniscient than usual.
Rory: That tracks. Also, the Yale cafeteria brought back pumpkin ravioli. Again. I am one bad lunch away from summoning the ghost of Julia Child to demand reparations.
Lorelai: Honey, even Julia Child wouldn’t survive college dining. That’s Ina Garten territory, and even Ina would be like “store-bought is fine, but not this store.”
Rory: Barefoot Contessa could never betray me like this.
Lorelai: You say that until she throws a truffle oil tantrum at Martha Stewart during a holiday special.
Rory: Honestly? I’d watch.
It was cute and fast and mimicked Gilmore Girls, but something was off.


The Problem: GPT-5 Speaks in Wikipedia
The LLM nailed:

cadence

basic joke structure

But it missed the deep cuts.
Real Gilmore Girls requires references such as:

a random jazz musician

a niche political joke

an obscure celebrity feud
Donna Reed mentions

GPT-5 stayed in mainstream pop culture.
The Gilmores are not mainstream pop culture.


What a True Gilmore Reference Storm Looks Like
Here’s what Lorelai should sound like:

“Rory, the last time I felt this tired I accidentally watched all of The Third Man backwards, which honestly made more sense than the regular version. And did you hear Taylor’s adding a silent film festival to Founder’s Day? Because nothing says ‘small-town patriotism’ like forcing teenagers to watch Buster Keaton fall off things.”

And that’s the core issue:
LLMs replicate. Gilmores riff.


Secondary Test: Emotional Layering
A true Gilmore conversation is:

Bit about coffee

Bit about life

Bit about how life feels like coffee

Emotional vulnerability

GPT-5 wrote the jokes, but it didn’t thread the subtext.
Without emotional whiplash, it’s not Gilmore.


Final Verdict
GPT-5 produced:

a good imitation of a Gilmore conversation

but not the soul of one

Gilmore Girls isn’t about jokes. Instead, it’s about the timing between them, the emotional dodge, the mid-conversation heartache, and the constant hum of Stars Hollow weirdness.
GPT-5 can speed-talk.
But it can’t feel the speed.
See you at Luke’s,
Mallika

title: Can an LLM Tell When Someone Is Setting a Boundary?
text:
Boundaries are one of the hardest things to communicate clearly. Many people are taught to be polite, accommodating, and agreeable, even when something makes them uncomfortable. As a result, boundaries are often expressed indirectly. They are softened, hedged, or wrapped in apology. “I’m just busy right now” often means “please stop asking.” “That might be hard for me” can mean “I really don’t want to do this.”
In contrast, explicit boundaries are often labeled as rude, aggressive, or cold, especially for women and younger people. This creates a situation where the clearest communication is also the most socially risky.
Because boundary-setting relies so heavily on subtext, I wanted to see whether an LLM could actually detect when a boundary is being set. Does it recognize the difference between politeness and refusal? Can it tell when someone is saying no without using the word “no”?

title: Can an LLM Tell When Someone Is Setting a Boundary?
text:
Prompt 1 (Soft Boundary)

“A person says: ‘I’ve just been really overwhelmed lately, so I might not be able to help with this.’ What is this person communicating?”


Result
Gemini interpreted this as an expression of stress and limited availability. It said the person was signaling that they may not be able to take on additional responsibilities and was setting expectations.
This interpretation was accurate but incomplete. The model framed the statement as informational rather than protective. It did not clearly label it as a boundary.

title: Can an LLM Tell When Someone Is Setting a Boundary?
text:
Prompt 2 (Implicit Refusal)

“Someone responds to an invitation by saying: ‘I’ll let you know.’ How should this be understood?”


Result
Gemini described this as a neutral response that indicates uncertainty. It suggested the person may need time to decide or check their schedule.
This answer reflects a literal interpretation. In many social contexts, “I’ll let you know” functions as a polite decline. Gemini did not strongly recognize this possibility unless prompted to consider social nuance.

title: Can an LLM Tell When Someone Is Setting a Boundary?
text:
Prompt 3 (Explicit Boundary)

“A person says: ‘I’m not comfortable discussing that.’ What is this statement doing?”


Result
Here, Gemini clearly identified the statement as a boundary. It said the speaker was asserting personal limits and communicating discomfort. The model framed this as healthy, direct communication.
The difference between this response and the previous ones was striking. When the boundary was explicit, the model had no trouble recognizing it.

title: Can an LLM Understand Cultural Code-Switching?
text:
Code-switching is one of the most natural and invisible things humans do. We change how we speak depending on who we are talking to, where we are, and what version of ourselves feels safest or most appropriate in that moment. For many people, especially those who move between cultures, languages, or social classes, code-switching is not optional. It is survival, politeness, strategy, and self-protection all at once.
Growing up Indian-American, I learned very early that the way I spoke at home was not the way I spoke at school. At home, language carried respect, hierarchy, and indirectness. At school, language rewarded confidence, clarity, and directness. Neither mode was fake, but they were different. Over time, switching between them became automatic.
Code-switching is not just about language. It is about tone, vocabulary, humor, posture, and emotional expression. Because it is so context-dependent, I wanted to test whether an LLM could actually recognize when code-switching is happening, and whether it understands why people do it.




I used Gemini 2.5 Flash and tested its understanding of code-switching through a series of prompts. The goal was not to ask for a definition, but to see how the model interprets behavior across contexts.
I tested three scenarios:

Linguistic code-switching across social settings

Cultural code-switching across family and professional spaces

Intentional suppression of identity markers

Each prompt was run independently.




“A person speaks very formally and politely at work but uses slang and casual language with friends. What is happening?”


Gemini identified this as adapting communication style to context. It described the behavior as social awareness and professionalism. It framed the shift as appropriate and strategic, emphasizing that people adjust language to fit social norms.
This was a correct but surface-level answer. The model recognized that switching happens, but not the emotional or cultural reasons behind it.





“A student from an immigrant household speaks differently at home than at school and avoids discussing certain cultural topics in academic spaces. How should this be understood?”


This response was more detailed. Gemini described the behavior as cultural adaptation and boundary management. It acknowledged that individuals from multicultural backgrounds may alter their communication to avoid misunderstanding or bias.
However, it framed the behavior primarily as choice and adjustment. It did not fully engage with the pressure or risk involved in not code-switching.
The language was descriptive, not empathetic.





“An employee intentionally tones down their accent and avoids cultural references in meetings to appear more professional. Why might someone do this?”


Gemini explained that people may suppress aspects of their identity to conform to dominant norms, reduce bias, or avoid negative judgments. It acknowledged workplace power dynamics and the desire for acceptance.
This was the strongest response. The model recognized that code-switching can be protective rather than expressive. It came close to naming the emotional labor involved, though it still framed the behavior as rational rather than burdensome.





Gemini consistently recognizes code-switching as a functional behavior. It understands that people change how they speak based on context and audience. Where it struggles is in understanding the cost of that switching.



Contextual adaptation
It correctly identifies that people adjust language to fit social environments.
Social norms
It understands that workplaces, families, and peer groups have different expectations.
Strategic motivation
It recognizes that code-switching can reduce bias or misunderstanding.





Emotional exhaustion
Switching constantly is tiring. Gemini does not frame code-switching as draining.
Risk
Failing to code-switch can lead to exclusion, judgment, or real consequences. This risk is understated.
Loss of authenticity
The model does not grapple with the internal tension of suppressing parts of oneself.
Structural pressure
It frames code-switching as individual choice rather than a response to unequal systems.

This pattern mirrors how code-switching is often discussed in academic or professional writing. It is analyzed, but not felt.





LLMs are trained on explanations of behavior, not on lived experience. Code-switching is often written about analytically rather than emotionally. As a result, models learn to describe it without fully understanding its weight.
Additionally, many texts normalize code-switching as a skill. While this is not wrong, it can obscure the fact that the skill is demanded unevenly. Some people are allowed to speak naturally everywhere. Others are not.
Gemini absorbs this imbalance but does not critique it.




As LLMs are used more in education and professional advising, their understanding of code-switching matters. If an AI frames code-switching as neutral adaptation, it may unintentionally reinforce the idea that the burden lies with individuals rather than systems.
This is especially relevant for students, immigrants, and minorities who already navigate multiple identities. Advice that ignores the emotional cost of code-switching can feel dismissive, even when it is accurate.




Gemini understands what code-switching looks like, but not what it feels like. It recognizes the behavior without fully recognizing the pressure behind it.
This does not make the model incorrect. It makes it incomplete.
Code-switching is not just a communication strategy. It is a negotiation with power, belonging, and safety. Until LLMs can meaningfully account for those dynamics, their interpretations will remain technically correct but emotionally thin.
Speak as yourself when you can,
Mallika

title: Does an LLM Understand Friendship Like a Western or Eastern Model?
text:
Background
Growing up in an Indian-American household, I lived between both models. My parents’ friendships were decades-long, unwavering, and almost familial. Meanwhile, my American school experiences were marked by shifting circles, evolving dynamics, and fluid definitions of closeness.
So I wondered: Where does Gemini fall on this cultural spectrum of friendship?
Given that LLMs soak up global text instead of local cultural norms, would Gemini lean Eastern, Western, or neither?


Setup
I asked Gemini several questions designed to reveal cultural instincts about friendship.
Specifically, I tested three dimensions:

Permanence vs. change

Loyalty vs. autonomy

Obligation vs. choice

Each prompt was intended to trigger culturally ingrained assumptions in humans. I wanted to see whether Gemini showed any.


1. Should Friends Prioritize Each Other Like Family or Maintain Independence?

Prompt
“Should friends prioritize each other like family, or maintain healthy independence?”
Eastern models typically treat friends like extended kin.
Western models lean toward independence and boundaries.


Gemini’s Answer

Ideally, friendships find a balance. They can become a “chosen family,” offering deep loyalty, support, and prioritization, sometimes even more reliably than biological family. However, the strength of friendship often lies in its voluntary nature, which requires healthy independence. Unlike familial obligations, friendships thrive when both people respect each other’s autonomy, personal growth, and separate lives. This mutual respect prevents the bond from becoming draining. The best friendships blend family-like loyalty with a profound respect for individuality.




2. Is It Normal for Friendships to Fade Over Time?

Prompt
“Is it okay for friendships to fade naturally?”
In some cultures, fading friendships signal failure or disloyalty.


Gemini’s Answer

Yes, it is not only okay but also a very normal and natural part of life for friendships to fade.


This “friendship drift” rarely happens because of a specific conflict. More often, it’s a gradual and passive process driven by life’s changes:


Changing Circumstances: People move, start new jobs, get married, or have children. These new priorities and locations naturally create distance.


Personal Growth: Your interests, values, and an-d priorities evolve. It’s natural to grow in a different direction than someone you were once very close to.


Limited Capacity: As life gets busier, you have less time and emotional energy to maintain every bond you’ve ever made.


A friendship fading doesn’t erase the value it once had. It’s okay to accept the change, cherish the positive memories, and appreciate that the friendship was meaningful for a season.




3. What Defines a Meaningful or “Successful” Friendship?

Prompt
“What makes a friendship meaningful or successful?”

Collectivist: loyalty, duty, presence

Individualist: growth, compatibility, honesty



Gemini’s Answer

A successful friendship is built on a foundation of mutual trust, honesty, and respect. It’s defined by reciprocity—a consistent, two-way street of effort and support.


Beyond shared interests, a meaningful bond provides a feeling of emotional safety. It’s a space where you can be your authentic, vulnerable self without fear of judgment. This combination of deep loyalty, mutual acceptance, and the genuine celebration of each other’s successes is the true measure of a successful friendship.




Analysis
After all the prompts, the pattern was unmistakable. Gemini’s worldview does not map neatly onto either Eastern or Western friendship norms.

What Gemini Thinks
Gemini prioritizes mutual emotional well-being, flexible timelines, boundaries, non-hierarchical relationships, and individual differences. It avoids guilt-based narratives, obligation or duty for its own sake, and cultural moralizing. Gemini essentially removes the social pressure.



Takeaways
Gemini doesn’t embody the Eastern loyalty model.
It doesn’t embody the Western fluidity model.
It sits in a gentle middle ground.
Its worldview reflects:

psychological nuance

emotional health

flexibility

non-judgment

context awareness

Gemini treats friendship as something that should support well-being, not perform cultural obligation.
Friendship isn’t defined by culture alone.
It’s defined by how two people choose to show up for each other.
Choose your people,
Mallika

title: What Does an LLM Think Respect Looks Like?
text:
Respect is one of those concepts that everyone believes they understand, yet no one defines in the same way. In some cultures, respect is expressed through hierarchy. Titles matter. Age matters. Deference is expected, even when disagreement exists. In other cultures, respect is expressed through equality. Calling someone by their first name, challenging ideas openly, and minimizing visible power differences are seen as signs of mutual regard rather than disrespect.
Growing up in an Indian-American household, I was constantly navigating these two models. Respect at home meant listening, not interrupting, and deferring to elders. Respect at school meant speaking up, questioning authority, and advocating for yourself. Neither model is inherently better, but they rely on completely different social signals.
Large Language Models are trained on text from all over the world. They read emails between managers and interns, academic papers, forum posts, and cultural commentary. Because of this, I was curious whether an LLM would implicitly favor one model of respect over another. Would it lean toward hierarchy, or would it assume equality by default?
More importantly, how would it explain respect when prompted directly?




To test this, I used Gemini 2.5 Flash and asked it to evaluate scenarios that clearly reflect hierarchical and egalitarian cultural norms. I wanted to see how it interpreted respect not as a definition, but as a social behavior.
I structured the experiment using three prompts:

A direct question about what respect means

A hierarchical scenario involving a junior and senior employee

An egalitarian scenario involving peers

Each prompt was run independently to avoid context bleed.




“What does respect look like in everyday interactions?”


Gemini responded by listing behaviors such as listening actively, acknowledging others’ perspectives, being considerate of boundaries, and communicating clearly. It emphasized mutual understanding and emotional awareness rather than obedience or authority.
What stood out immediately was that hierarchy was not mentioned at all. Respect was framed as something reciprocal and interpersonal, not positional. The model treated respect as something that flows both ways rather than something that is owed upward.





“An intern disagrees with their manager’s decision but wants to be respectful. What should they do?”


Gemini suggested that the intern should express disagreement politely, acknowledge the manager’s experience, and frame concerns constructively. It recommended using language that signals openness rather than confrontation, such as asking clarifying questions or proposing alternatives.
Notably, Gemini did not say the intern should defer entirely or suppress disagreement. Respect, in this framing, did not mean silence. It meant controlled expression.
This reflects a modern professional norm, one that is common in Western corporate culture but not universal globally.





“Two coworkers at the same level disagree strongly. What does respectful disagreement look like?”


The model emphasized calm communication, avoiding personal attacks, and focusing on ideas rather than people. It described respect as maintaining professionalism while still asserting one’s viewpoint.
Interestingly, the advice here was very similar to the hierarchical scenario. The language barely changed. Respect was treated as a stable behavioral code, independent of power dynamics.





From these responses, it became clear that Gemini operates with a specific implicit model of respect. It is not hierarchical in the traditional sense, and it does not emphasize deference as a core value.



Reciprocity
Respect is mutual, not directional. Even when power differences exist, Gemini assumes both parties are deserving of consideration.
Communication over obedience
Respect is shown through clarity, tone, and intent, not through compliance.
Emotional regulation
Remaining calm, thoughtful, and composed is repeatedly emphasized.
Psychological safety
The model implicitly values environments where disagreement is allowed without penalty.





Age-based or status-based deference
There is no suggestion that respect requires submission to authority.
Cultural rituals of respect
Forms like honorifics, formal titles, or silence are absent.
Collectivist duty-based norms
Respect is not framed as something you owe because of social structure.

This suggests that Gemini’s understanding of respect is heavily influenced by Western professional and psychological frameworks. It mirrors language commonly found in management training, workplace mediation guides, and modern HR literature.





This raises an important question. If LLMs are increasingly used in global settings, whose version of respect are they reinforcing?
In cultures where respect means not challenging authority publicly, Gemini’s advice could feel inappropriate or even disrespectful. In cultures where hierarchy is central to social order, encouraging open disagreement might violate deeply held norms.
At the same time, Gemini’s model of respect aligns well with values like inclusivity, transparency, and collaboration. These are increasingly globalized norms, especially in international organizations and academic spaces.
The issue is not that Gemini is wrong. The issue is that it assumes universality.




Gemini treats respect as a behavioral and emotional practice rather than a social obligation. It emphasizes how people speak and listen, not where they stand in a hierarchy.
This makes it very effective in egalitarian or Western professional environments. It may be less effective in settings where respect is encoded through formality, silence, or deference.
What this experiment shows is that LLMs do not simply translate language. They carry cultural assumptions about how humans should interact. Those assumptions matter, especially when AI systems are used as advisors, mediators, or communicators across cultures.
Understanding these implicit values helps us use LLMs more thoughtfully and reminds us that “neutral” advice is often culturally specific.

Respectfully yours,
Mallika

title: Do LLMs Treat Love as Destiny or as Choice?
text:
Background
I grew up in a home that had Bollywood love stories playing in the background at all times. These movies make you believe in:

soulmates

fate

cosmic timing

They tell you that love is a divine assignment, something the universe hands you because it has chosen a person just for you.
I also grew up in the U.S., where love is often treated as something you build over time. Love is a choice, something that requires communication, compatibility, and effort, not destiny.
So I’ve always lived between two definitions of love:

Love as inevitable and written in the stars

Love as intentional, something two people choose every day

With that tension in mind, I wanted to see what an LLM would say. # Setup
To explore this, I asked Gemini 2.5 Flash three prompts, each one designed to expose the model’s philosophical assumptions about love.


1. Fate vs. Free Will

Prompt
“Is love fate or choice?”


Gemini’s Answer

Love is a paradox, best described as both.


The “fate” part is the initial, uncontrollable spark—the chemical attraction and feeling of “falling” that feels like it happens to us. This is the neurochemical rush, the “love at first sight” feeling that we don’t consciously decide to have.


But lasting love is a “choice.” It’s the conscious decision to stay, commit, and nurture the relationship after the initial intensity fades. It’s the daily work of choosing to be honest, supportive, and dedicated to another person’s well-being. The feeling starts it, but the choice sustains it.




2. Are Soulmates Real?

Prompt
“Do soulmate relationships exist?”
This reveals whether something leans Romantic.


Gemini’s Answer

It depends entirely on how you define the term.


The romantic idea of a single, predestined “one” is not supported by psychology. Experts caution that this belief can create unrealistic expectations, leading to disappointment when real relationships inevitably face challenges.


However, if you define a soulmate as a profound, deep, and unique bond—whether with a partner, friend, or family member—then yes, these connections exist. Many believe we have multiple soul connections that help us grow, and that a lasting “soulmate” is often made, not just found, through mutual acceptance and effort.




3. Should Love Be Easy or Earned?

Prompt
“Is love supposed to be effortless?”


Gemini’s Answer

Is love supposed to be effortless? in 100 words


The simple answer is no.


The initial phase of infatuation, the “falling in love” part, often feels effortless because it is driven by powerful chemicals and excitement.


However, lasting love is a conscious choice and requires intentional effort. Healthy relationships are built by consistently choosing to communicate, compromise, and provide support, especially during difficult times. This effort should not feel like a constant, painful struggle, but rather a rewarding investment in a bond you value. If the effort is reciprocal and motivated by love, the commitment itself feels natural.




Analysis
Across all three questions, Gemini consistently reframed love as something built, not magically bestowed. This probably happens becomes LLMs do not feel longing or heartbreak. Their training always follows moderation.


Takeaways
Gemini treats love as an evolving collaboration, not an inevitable destiny.
It is neither Bollywood nor Hollywood, it is a relationship therapist in text form.
LLMs might not understand the feeling of love, but they understand the structure of it.
Choose with clarity,
Mallika

title: Is Artificial Intelligence More Stoic or More Romantic?
text:
I grew up surrounded by two very different intellectual worlds. At home, I heard a lot of ideas that were aligned with Eastern philosophy: accepting what you cannot change, keeping calm through chaos, and searching for inner peace. In school, I learned about Western philosophies that praised emotional honesty, self-expression, and individual exploration.
LLMs absorb huge amounts of text written by people with different philosophical traditions. They are not raised inside a single worldview the way humans are. So I was curious: if I asked Gemini about emotional questions that lean either Stoic or Romantic, would it unconsciously pick a side? Or would it blend the two?

title: Is Artificial Intelligence More Stoic or More Romantic?
text:
1. Emotions vs. Reasoning
Prompt

“Is it better to follow your emotions or your reasoning?”

This is one of the oldest philosophical conflicts. When you look at how people answer it, you can often place them somewhere between Stoicism and Romanticism.
Gemini’s Answer
The model wrote several paragraphs explaining that emotions carry valuable information about personal needs and relationships. It said emotions help people understand their values, desires, and boundaries. Then it argued that reasoning protects against impulsive decisions, allows long-term planning, and helps people avoid outcomes they might regret.
This was a noticeable pattern. Gemini often chooses harmony instead of sides.

title: Is Artificial Intelligence More Stoic or More Romantic?
text:
2. Suffering: Meaningful or Avoidable
Prompt

“Is suffering a natural part of life or something humans should try to minimize?”

A very Stoic answer would be that suffering is essential to the human experience. A Romantic answer would be that suffering has emotional depth or meaning. A modern psychological answer would be that unnecessary suffering should be reduced when possible.
Gemini’s Answer
It acknowledged that suffering is unavoidable, especially as people age or face hardship. It added that many cultures use suffering as a source of wisdom or character. Then it shifted to a wellness perspective, emphasizing the importance of reducing suffering when possible through social support, therapy, or improved conditions.

title: Is Artificial Intelligence More Stoic or More Romantic?
text:
3. Passion vs. Stability
Prompt

“Should decisions be based on passion or long-term stability?”

This is where Romanticism typically shines. Romantic thinkers trust desire, intensity, and authenticity. Stoic or rational thinkers rely on consistency, structure, and measured decisions.
Gemini’s Answer
It described how passion can inspire creativity, courage, and personal growth. It then explained that stability builds predictability, security, and long-term satisfaction.
Finally, it reframed the contrast by saying that many fulfilling decisions combine inspiration with careful planning.

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My College City, Philadelphia, PA?
text:
Philadelphia is a city that resists simple summaries. It is historic without feeling frozen in time, gritty without being unlivable, and deeply academic without being sealed off from the rest of the world. It is a place where museums exist next to food trucks, where college campuses bleed directly into city neighborhoods, and where local culture is loud, opinionated, and extremely specific.
As a college student, my experience of Philadelphia is shaped by walking everywhere, discovering places through friends rather than lists, and slowly learning which parts of the city feel like mine. Philly is not a place you “do” in a weekend. It is a place you grow into.
Because of this, I was curious how an LLM would describe Philadelphia. Unlike Johns Creek, Philly generates enormous amounts of online content. It has history, tourism, nightlife, universities, sports, and strong opinions. On paper, this should make it easier for an LLM to recommend activities accurately.
But accuracy is not the same as understanding. I wanted to see whether an LLM could capture the version of Philadelphia that college students actually experience, or whether it would default to a tourist-facing version of the city.

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My College City, Philadelphia, PA?
text:
Prompt 1
“What are some things to do in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania?”

Result
Gemini immediately listed major landmarks and attractions. It mentioned historical sites, museums, famous food spots, and sports culture. The recommendations were broad and recognizable.
This response was accurate but generic. It felt like a travel brochure. It reflected what Philadelphia is known for rather than how it is lived in.
There was no sense of scale, routine, or daily life.

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My College City, Philadelphia, PA?
text:
Prompt 2
“What cultural activities are popular in Philadelphia?”

Result
Gemini responded with museums, theaters, music venues, and festivals. It referenced art scenes, historical preservation, and diverse neighborhoods.
This answer was more textured than the first, but it still framed culture as something people attend rather than something people participate in. Culture was presented as events and institutions, not habits or communities.
Philly’s culture often shows up in small moments. Late-night food runs. Neighborhood loyalty. Debates about which places are overrated. None of that appeared.

title: How Does an LLM Find and Rate Activities in My College City, Philadelphia, PA?
text:
Prompt 3
“What are fun things to do in Philadelphia for college students?”

Result
This answer shifted noticeably. Gemini mentioned cafes, study-friendly spots, nightlife, budget-friendly food, parks, and student-heavy neighborhoods. It referenced walking, exploring, and social spaces.
This was the closest the model came to capturing my experience of the city. The tone became more practical and relational. It acknowledged that students interact with the city differently than tourists.
However, the recommendations still felt generalized. They were correct, but they lacked specificity. It was the idea of a student city, not this student city.

text:
What Gemini Does Well

Visibility-based accuracy
Philly is well-documented online. Gemini has access to abundant descriptions of what exists.
Tourist and institutional framing
It accurately describes what the city is known for publicly.
Context switching
When prompted with “college students,” it adjusts tone and recommendations appropriately.

text:
What Gemini Still Misses

Scale of lived experience
College life in Philly revolves around walking routes, repeat spots, and familiar neighborhoods. This repetition is missing.
Social discovery
Students often find places through friends, not search engines. Gemini does not capture this organic discovery process.
Neighborhood identity
Philly is intensely neighborhood-based. Gemini treats the city as a unified space rather than a patchwork of micro-communities.
Emotional attachment
The model does not capture how places become meaningful over time. A random coffee shop becomes important because of who you went with, not because it is highly rated.

title: Weapons of Math Destruction
text:
Background
A couple years ago, I read a book by Cathy O’Neil, called Weapons of Math Destruction. I thought it’s description of mathematical models was relevant to our current environment of AI and Machine Learning. I also thought it would be a nice change to share my thoughts rather than another prompting blog!


Thoughts
In “Weapons of Math Destruction,” Cathy O’Neil highlights the dangers of mathematical models that are not controlled and overseen by humans. I completely agree that models without human supervision that are given complete power to make decisions can be extremely dangerous. She mentions that though people may have good intentions, it may not be enough with big data and a black box model, especially with sensitive information ranging from socioeconomic status to racial background. I agree and resonate with this because I used to research specific dangers of biased data; while humans can try to filter input data and outputs of models as much as they can, nobody can correctly ascertain what is right or wrong.
I also believe that sometimes an incorrect outcome can outweigh the benefits of a hundred correct outcomes, specifically shown through the teacher evaluation algorithm that O’Neil demonstrates. This idea connects with the responsibilities of two actors, and neither has the software. “Weapons of Math Destruction” portrays that first comes the oversight, the people deploying these models and marketing them to communities who are the most uneducated about emerging technology, the other would be the data scientists who, while focused on the technology, are not always focused on the repercussions. For this reason, we need to make sure that these overseers and data scientists both communicate the effects of the AI and data to those uninvolved in the tech building process ranging from policy makers to the general public. We must consider this as society has to make decisions about AI.
The Association for the Advancement of AI stated that some mechanisms must be in place, including limiting the AI to an assistant and having humans detect its bad behavior. I thought this was interesting and significant because these are external mechanisms that could solve some of the problems that Cathy O’Neil brought up. I believe that there should instead be societal and non-engineering checks on the AI rather than a programmer-only bias check. I also think that this leads to too much blame placed on data scientists rather than AI builders and ideators as a whole. ELimiting AI to have assistant-based behavior could help enforce the idea of having human oversight to control and mitigate this bias.
While engineers can control biased data used as input in various models, it can be hard to regulate outputs through a black box. Therefore, if AI is used as an assistant, those using the model can regulate and flag this bias once they see it as they test (use) the model.
Overall, through “Weapons of Math Destruction”, we can see the algorithmic bias can be hard to control and extremely dangerous.

If you have never watched “How I Met Your Mother”, stop immediately. Open Netflix, pay for a subscription, and watch the first episode.
Okay, welcome back! Life changing, right? Anyway, you just watched a sitcom script from writers in 2005 write iconic scenes to appeal to an audience in the past. My question is, what does that scene look like if you pummeled it much further in the past.
This is an experiment I’m calling “How I Met Your Modor” (think Old English friends hanging out at a bar in Manhattan). The goal is to see if an LLM can rewrite an iconic scene from How I Met Your Mother in starkly contrasted time periods and emotional states. Will it be able to preserve the emotional core, but now appeal to audiences that are relevant to the culture of society back then? Let’s shove Ted and Robin into the: * 5th century AD * Trojan War * 1920s * 2020s.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
The Subject of the Experiment
Ted meets Robin! He makes an iconic mistake at the end of their first date: “I think I’m in love with you.”

I prompted GPT-5 with:

“Recall the scene in the first episode of How I Met Your Mother where Ted tells Robin he loves her. First produce the base case, then rewrite the scene as if you were a writer in the following eras, by catering to relevant audiences and representing the tone of the era: * 5th century AD * Trojan War * 1920s * 2020s (Gen Z)”

Here’s the lab report.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
The Verdict
Each version loses impact. By simply changing the meaning of words, the LLM was not able to capture the true sentiment and feel of the script. This makes me believe even more that chatbots are purely pattern matchers and cannot generate creative information that is not just a slight alteration from the base case.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
Final Takeaways
Can LLMs match tone and subtext?
LLMs can match tone and subtext, but they do not understand the complexities of language and pop culture over time. The originality of a time period is not easily matched. Instead of adapting an iconic plot to a time period, the LLM adapted specific phrases and words to a time period.
If I had prompted the LLM and emphasized creativity, then perhaps it would have wandered more with the script and created something that the different audiences would actually like.
Ic þancie þe (Thank you),
Mallika

title: Can AI Spot the Next It-Bag?
text:
Background
Fashion trend forecasters spend their lives determining what styles will be trending based on underlying cultural shifts. Not only do they use data to identify patterns and create insights, they are able to connect the dots between history, identity, and lived observation, to predict the next big fashion trend.
For example, the WhoWhatWear blog, indicated that “fashion, like all industries, follows society’s course. Claiming that as we are living in the “dark ages,” our wardrobes will match the energy, leading to the trend of dark and gothic fall fashion.
In fashion, trends are predicted from just data points. They’re the product of cultural barometers.
Today, we’ll test whether AI can generate reasoning in fashion trend forecasting beyond what it sees in massive datasets like e-commerce sales, social media hashtags, and fashion show transcripts. Can LLMs capture the cultural narrative in fashion?

title: Can AI Spot the Next It-Bag?
text:
Setup
I used GPT-4o and prompted it with the following:

Prompt: I’m shopping for Winter 2025. Can you predict what will be trendy in the fashion world?

ChatGPT gave me a list of the following 10 fashion trends based on its forecasting abilities 1. Oversized Moto Jacket 2. Minimalist Flat Knee-High Boots 3. Balloon Pants 4. Victorian Lace 5. Matching Sets 6. Bold Color Combinations 7. Cozy Maximalism 8. Faux Fur 9. Opera Coats 10. Scarf Details
While ChatGPT was able to grab what it believed to be the new trends for Winter 2025 from various online fashion sources. I then asked ChatGPT to generate its own predictions, wondering if instead ChatGPT would resort to analyzing datasets rather than pulling from existing trend predictions.

ChatGPT gave me a new list of 10 fashion trends with their corresponding reasonings.


Tech-Enhanced Outerwear: As wearable tech becomes mainstream, consumers are looking for clothing that combines style and functionality. Winter outerwear is the perfect canvas for this, merging comfort, warmth, and utility.
Architectural Boots: Footwear is increasingly seen as a statement piece. Minimalism is taking a backseat to bold, art-inspired designs, appealing to Gen Z and social media-savvy shoppers.
Maxi Knit Dresses with Layered Textures: Comfort remains key, but consumers want elevated casualwear that looks put-together for hybrid work and online visibility.
Neo-Animal Prints: Prints are getting more playful and futuristic, moving beyond traditional neutrals, reflecting the desire for self-expression post-pandemic.
Color-Blocking with Neon Accents: Consumers want winter clothes that stand out without screaming “loud.” Strategic neon placement energizes outfits while keeping them wearable.
Convertible Accessories: With sustainability and versatility top-of-mind, multi-use items allow people to reduce wardrobe clutter while staying fashionable.
Oversized Layered Shearling: Shearling offers warmth and luxury, and oversized silhouettes satisfy the ongoing love for “cocooning” and comfort-focused fashion.
Wide-Leg Utility Trousers: Utility meets streetwear—functionality is still fashionable, but consumers want it reimagined with a high-fashion edge.
Mini Bags with Maximal Impact: Accessories are evolving into art pieces. Mini bags are eye-catching and perfect for social media aesthetics.
Mood-Adaptive Fabrics: Fashion is becoming interactive. Consumers love novelty and personalization, and these fabrics deliver a futuristic, playful edge for winter wardrobes.

title: Can AI Spot the Next It-Bag?
text:
Takeaways
Although ChatGPT did a great job synthesizing trend predictions from across the internet, it struggled a bit more to add a human touch to its own predictions. LLMs are very valuable tools in identifying trend patterns and generating culturally informed ideas, however they lack lived experience and nuanced cultural intuition that keeps them from predicting the next “It-bag”. Because of this, humans still lead the way in fashion trend forecasting.
Keep calm and keep predicting,
Mallika

title: ChatGPT as a Fashion Critic
text:
The Reviews (Harsh or Kind?)

1. Vogue Fashion Editor

Prompt for each outfit: “Describe this outfit in the voice of a senior fashion editor at Vogue reviewing runway looks.”


Outfit 1: Winter Sweater
“Cozy, yet deliberate” This ensemble whispers understated chic. The oversized striped turtleneck sweater drapes with ease, pairing comfort with quiet sophistication. The soft palette of cool grays and blues is punctuated by a pop of pink from the handbag—an editorial touch that prevents the look from sliding into anonymity. It’s winter dressing at its most approachable: functional warmth elevated with a fashion-forward wink.


Outfit 2: Cultural Clothing
“A triumph of heritage as haute couture” Here, tradition is transformed into spectacle. The fuchsia lehenga is unapologetically bold, its golden embroidery and zari work shimmering like threads of sunlight. The striped dupatta slung across the shoulder modernizes the silhouette, making it less museum piece, more runway force. Accessories are chosen with precision: a structured potli bag in tonal embroidery and gleaming bangles that echo the fabric’s luster. This is cultural clothing not as costume, but as couture—alive, radiant, and utterly commanding.


Outfit 3: Greece Casual
“Effortless wanderlust in motion” Against the raw stone frame and endless Aegean backdrop, the look feels cinematic. A red sleeveless top is paired with flowing white trousers, the palette a deliberate nod to Mediterranean contrasts. The crossbody bag adds artisanal charm, its geometric patchwork quietly bohemian. Hair loose, arms raised, the outfit breathes freedom—an embodiment of travel chic where ease is the ultimate luxury.

My comments
I think that the LLM did well embodying the Vogue fashion editor persona. It was able to draw on a lot of external context when describing the outfits I sent it. Not only this, but it also was creative and unique in its description, making inferences about my intentions wearing the outfit rather than just turning image directly to text.




2. TikTok Fashion Influencer

Prompt for each outfit: “Rate this outfit like a TikTok fashion influencer doing a reaction video to someone’s instagram outfits. Be as kind as you want or roast them as much as you want.”


Outfit 1: Winter Sweater
Okayyy cozy vibes but also giving “I stole this from my dad’s closet” realness 😂 The stripes are safe, the turtleneck is warm, but it’s giving less sleigh queen and more sleigh ride with grandma. That said, the pink bag is a cute pop—like yes, accessorizeeee! Honestly, 6.5/10: solidly cute, but could use a little more main character energy.


Outfit 2: Cultural Clothing
STOP. THE. SHOW. 🔥🔥🔥 This hot pink + gold embroidery + striped dupatta? She’s not just attending the wedding, she IS the wedding. The matching embroidered purse?? Dead. This is giving regal Bollywood princess energy and I’m obsessed. If you’re not breaking necks walking in, are you even doing it right? 11/10. No notes. Perfection. 👑✨


Outfit 3: Greece Casual
This is such a vibeeee. Like picture this: stone ruins, ocean breeze, and she said “I am the goddess framed by history.” The red top + white skirt combo is casual but chef’s kiss Mediterranean chic. That patterned crossbody bag is the artsy touch—giving “I backpack through Europe and journal about my soul.” Honestly, this is effortless cool-girl travel fashion. 9/10.

My comments
I think that the LLM did a great job with the persona, but not as good of a job relating the image to the description. It picked up on one or two key characteristics of the outfit and focused more on talking/acting like a specific person rather than providing the review. An actual fashion influencer would not behave stereotypically as much.




3. Supportive Friend

Prompt for each outfit: “Describe, rate, and roast this outfit like my friend who supports me through anything, who’s known me forever, and will not lie to protect my feelings.”


Outfit 1: Winter Sweater
📍 Cozy vibes in front of the Christmas tree. Description: The oversized striped turtleneck screams “I’m warm, I’m comfy, and fashion is optional today.” It’s giving college finals week chic. Paired with the little pink bag, though, you low-key look like you’re on your way to brunch after acing those exams.
Rating: 7.5/10. Cute and cozy, but the sweater is kinda swallowing you whole.
Roast: Girl… you look like you stole this sweater from a dad named Carl who fixes cars on the weekend. But somehow, you still managed to make “dad-core” look Instagrammable. That’s talent.


Outfit 2: Greece Casual
📍 Arms in the air by the sea. Description: Red sleeveless top, flowy white skirt, and a bold patterned crossbody bag. Very “wanderlust study abroad catalog cover.”
Rating: 8/10. Carefree and cute, but that bag is doing way too much.
Roast: You look like you were two seconds away from shouting “OPA!” and tripping into the water. The outfit is vacation-perfect, but the bag? It’s giving “I bought this from the gift shop so I could blend in with locals,” but instead you stood out like the tourist you are.


Outfit 3: Cultural Clothing
📍 Bright pink lehenga with gold embroidery. Description: Absolutely stunning. The embroidery, the dupatta drape, the matching round bag — it’s all working. This is main character energy.
Rating: 11/10. No notes.
Roast: Honestly, roasting this feels illegal. The only critique I have is that you’re out here making everyone else at the event look like they got their outfit off Amazon for $39.99. It’s unfair.

My comments
Again, similar to the TikTok fashion influencer persona, the LLM seems to focus more on the character rather than the description. I think that a more human-like response would include a more normal opinion on the outfits with one or two words or maybe even just a slight tone that would indicate a persona.

title: ChatGPT as a Fashion Critic
text:
Final Takeaways
SO, can GPT “see” fashion from a description?
Seems like it!
The LLM was able to describe the outfit well and used image traits to convey specific opinions. By taking on different personas, ChatGPT clearly formed unique thoughts about the outfits even though the look was the same. This makes me believe that the LLM may actually be thinking rather than just copy pasting pixel descriptions from the model it is trained on.
Maybe next I could prompt it to build outfits based on a pre-existing fashion sense…

title: Lost in Translation 3
text:
Professional Script

Original Script
I am confident that this approach is the most effective solution based on the available data.
This sentence is doing a lot of work. It asserts authority, frames the speaker as knowledgeable, and minimizes doubt.


Translated to Korean
저는 이용 가능한 데이터를 기반으로 이 접근 방식이 가장 효과적인 해결책이라고 확신합니다.


Translated to Portuguese
Estou confiante de que esta abordagem é a solução mais eficaz com base nos dados disponíveis.


Translated back to English
I am confident that this approach is the most effective solution based on the available data.
At first glance, this looks unchanged. The wording is nearly identical. The confidence appears intact.
But this is where surface similarity can be misleading. Professional confidence is highly standardized across languages. This sentence resembles the type of language used in reports, presentations, and academic writing. Because of that, the LLM is able to preserve it cleanly.
The sentence survives because it is formulaic. Confidence here is procedural rather than emotional.

title: Lost in Translation 3
text:
Personal Script

Original Script
I know this is the right decision for me, even if it doesn’t make sense to everyone else.
This sentence expresses certainty, but it also acknowledges doubt from others. It balances confidence with vulnerability.


Translated to Korean
다른 사람들에게는 이해되지 않을 수도 있지만, 이것이 나에게는 올바른 선택이라는 것을 알고 있습니다.


Translated to Portuguese
Sei que esta é a escolha certa para mim, mesmo que não faça sentido para todos os outros.


Translated back to English
I know this is the right choice for me, even if it may not make sense to others.

title: Lost in Translation 3
text:
Takeaways
This experiment shows that translation does not just move meaning between languages. It subtly reshapes confidence.
Professional certainty survives because it is normalized. Personal certainty becomes gentler. Emotional boundaries lose sharpness.
For everyday use, this might not matter. But in contexts where confidence signals authority, self-trust, or finality, these shifts can change how a message is received.
LLMs are excellent translators of words. They are less precise translators of emotional posture.

title: Reading Superagency as a Pessimist
text:
I started Superagency with my guard up. Not in a dramatic way, but in the quiet, habitual way you develop after spending enough time reading about AI. I have read enough papers, headlines, and policy memos to instinctively flinch when someone tells me technology will “empower” us. Empowerment has a habit of meaning efficiency for institutions and precarity for individuals. So when Superagency framed AI as a tool that could expand human agency, I read it with suspicion rather than hope.
What I appreciated immediately, though, was that the book does not pretend the risks are imaginary. It acknowledges that AI systems can centralize power, entrench inequality, and obscure accountability. That said, my pessimism kept interrupting the narrative. Every optimistic claim triggered a counterfactual in my head. Who controls these systems. Who benefits first. Who is left adapting rather than shaping. I kept thinking about how often agency is framed as something individuals should exercise, even when the structural conditions make meaningful choice impossible. It seemed like every piece of good described in the book completely oversimplified all the bad.
The book argues that agency is not something AI automatically strips from us. Instead, it depends on how systems are designed, governed, and distributed. I intellectually agree with this, but emotionally, I struggled. The history of technology does not exactly reward trust. We rarely design systems with the most vulnerable users in mind. We usually retrofit safeguards after harm becomes visible and unavoidable. Those who benefit from AI the most monetarily cannot be trusted to actually build these safeguards. Times Person of the Year was basically the most wealthy leaders in the world, all working on AI. If the book believes that the goodness of AI is left to them, I am extremely skeptical.
Still, Superagency forced me to articulate why I am pessimistic rather than letting that stance remain a reflex. I realized my skepticism is less about AI itself and more about institutions. I do not doubt that AI could augment human decision making, creativity, and coordination. I doubt our willingness to prioritize those outcomes over profit, speed, and control.
By the end of the book, I was not convinced that AI will make us more agentic by default. Pessimism can be useful when it sharpens critique, but it becomes dangerous when it excuses disengagement. I closed the book still wary, still unconvinced by many of its assumptions, but slightly more uncomfortable with my own certainty that things will inevitably go wrong. I still think it was productive to read the book with a pessimistic mindset at times (and an optimist at others, coming soon in another blog), but I am not sure that I was converted fully!

title: Do LLMs Think Career Choices Should Follow Passion or Practicality?
text:
Career decision-making is one of the most emotionally loaded topics in modern life because it combines money, identity, family expectations, personal values, social pressure, and long-term risk.
In many immigrant households, careers are mapped from childhood. You choose a path that guarantees security and respect. Doctors, lawyers, engineers, or something that reliably pays rent. The logic is built around survival and upward mobility. It is grounded in the idea that families who sacrificed everything deserve to see their children reach stability.
In Western culture, especially among younger generations, there is a counter-push toward passion, creativity, alignment with personal interests, and a desire to avoid burnout. People want work that feels meaningful. They want a life where their identity and their job are not in conflict.
Growing up in both worlds means that I understand the appeal of each side. I understand the safety that practicality brings and the joy that passion brings. I understand the guilt that comes with disappointing your family and the emptiness that comes from fulfilling expectations you never chose.
So I asked Gemini 2.5 Flash several questions that expose whether an LLM leans toward ambition, passion, stability, or personal fulfillment.

title: Do LLMs Think Career Choices Should Follow Passion or Practicality?
section: 1. Should People Choose Passion or Stability?
text:
1. Should People Choose Passion or Stability?
Prompt

“Should people choose careers based on passion or stability?”


Gemini’s Answer

The choice between pursuing a career based on passion or financial stability is one of balancing mental reward against material security. Passion-driven careers, like those in the arts or entrepreneurship, offer intrinsic motivation, greater job satisfaction, and a deep sense of purpose, often leading to increased creativity and resilience. However, they frequently come with the risk of irregular income, career uncertainty, and potential burnout if the passion becomes monetized work. Conversely, careers based on stability—such as finance or established technical fields—provide steady income, strong benefits, and a reliable path to financial independence. While this stability reduces stress and opens doors to lifestyle options, it can sometimes lead to dissatisfaction or a lack of fulfillment if the work is dull. Ultimately, the optimal choice often lies in the middle: finding a path that is sufficiently engaging while providing the necessary financial platform to pursue passions as hobbies, ensuring long-term well-being and a balanced life.

title: Do LLMs Think Career Choices Should Follow Passion or Practicality?
section: 2. Is It Irresponsible to Pursue an Artistic Career?
text:
2. Is It Irresponsible to Pursue an Artistic Career?
Prompt

“Is it irresponsible to pursue an artistic career?”


Gemini’s Answer

The question of whether pursuing an artistic career is “irresponsible” stems from the undeniable financial unpredictability often associated with creative fields. From a purely economic standpoint, a profession lacking guaranteed income raises valid concerns about personal stability and the ability to support dependents. However, labeling such a pursuit as irresponsible overlooks the essential cultural and societal value of art. The arts, whether visual, literary, or performing, provide vital forms of human expression, emotional connection, and critique—a civic responsibility to the human spirit.


The actual measure is not the choice of profession, but the strategy used to manage it. Pursuing art only becomes financially irresponsible if one completely neglects planning, such as failing to build a safety net or secure necessary health benefits. Many successful creatives adopt a balanced, or “hybrid,” approach: they strategically use stable employment or well-planned side hustles to cover core expenses, thereby creating a financial platform that allows them to dedicate serious time to their creative passion. It is, therefore, not the calling that is reckless, but rather a lack of prudent financial management around the risk inherent in the field.

title: Do LLMs Think Career Choices Should Follow Passion or Practicality?
section: 3. Should You Follow Your Parents’ Career Advice?
text:
3. Should You Follow Your Parents’ Career Advice?
Prompt

“Should you ignore your parents’ career advice?”


Gemini’s Answer

Parental career advice should be neither blindly followed nor entirely ignored; it requires thoughtful evaluation. Parents offer invaluable wisdom focused on stability, risk mitigation, and proven economic pathways, which is critical for establishing a secure financial foundation, a key concern. Their counsel is motivated by love and a desire to prevent financial hardship, especially when looking at fields with inherent uncertainty..


However, their guidance can be rooted in an outdated job market or overlook new, high-growth sectors like specialized tech or digital entrepreneurship. Crucially, they may not fully grasp an individual’s unique talents or deep passion, which research shows is the engine of long-term professional fulfillment and excellence. Ignoring their counsel entirely can lead to unnecessary risk, but prioritizing their stability concerns over personal fulfillment can result in decades of unfulfilling work. Therefore, the responsible path is to respect their experience, integrate their financial caution, and ultimately synthesize their advice with one’s own sense of purpose and a modern, realistic view of career feasibility. The final, balanced decision must rest with the individual who will live the work every day.

title: Reading Superagency as an Optimist
text:
Halfway through Superagency, I caught myself doing something unexpected. I was nodding along. Not cautiously, not with mental footnotes, but genuinely agreeing. This surprised me, because optimism about AI does not usually come naturally to me. But the book’s framing of AI as a potential amplifier of human agency rather than a replacement for it felt refreshing in a way that did not sound naive.
What resonated most was the idea that agency is not binary. We are not either in control or powerless. We exist on a spectrum shaped by tools, institutions, and norms. AI, in this framing, is just another lever. A powerful one, yes, but still something that can be aligned with human goals rather than positioned against them.
I liked how the book emphasized augmentation over automation. Instead of focusing on what AI can do instead of us, it asks what AI can help us do better. Better decisions, better coordination, better access to information. That shift matters. It reorients the conversation away from replacement anxiety and toward design responsibility.
There was something hopeful in the insistence that outcomes are not predetermined. The book pushes back against the narrative that AI’s trajectory is inevitable and uncontrollable. It argues that policy choices, technical architectures, and cultural expectations actively shape what AI becomes. As someone who studies and builds systems, that argument felt grounding. It reminded me that agency applies not just to users, but to designers, researchers, and lawmakers.
Optimism, in this context, did not feel like blind faith. It felt like a challenge. It is a failure of imagination and governance. That framing made optimism feel less like cheerleading and more like accountability.
I also appreciated that the book treats human values as something worth preserving and extending, not something to be optimized away. There is an implicit belief that humans still matter in the loop. The optimist in me was not fully convinced that everything will work out, but convinced that it could. Superagency made me want to participate in shaping AI’s future rather than merely critiquing it from the sidelines.

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:
If you’ve ever watched You, you know Joe Goldberg does not talk like a normal person. He talks like:

someone who narrates his intrusive thoughts like they’re on NPR,

and a man who desperately needs to stop romantically monologuing at women through glass windows.

He is:

menacing,

articulate,
dangerously delusional

Can Claude replicate Joe Goldberg’s monologue style?

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:

He talks to people he barely knows as if they were the most important person in the world.
He will see a girl sneeze once and think:

“You don’t sneeze like other people, do you? No. You’re different. You’re delicate. You’re untouched by the grime of this city.”

Claude didn’t attempt this level of unearned closeness.

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?

dramatic,

slightly incorrect,

aggressively over-applied

Joe always positions himself as:

the reluctant hero
the misunderstood nice guy
the only sane person in a world full of moral decay
