title: Is ChatGPT a Swiftie?
text:
Background
Taylor Swift is a master of musical metaphors. She leaves her fans with riddles and puzzles to solve through her songs. The song Death by a Thousand Cuts, specifically has a large number of metaphors and ties to her past discography all analyzed by humans in Genius, the world’s biggest collection of song lyrics and musical knowledge.
Today, we’ll test whether AI can do more than just analyze but also understand the lived experience and emotional context behind Taylor Swift’s music.

title: Is ChatGPT a Swiftie?
text:
Setup
I asked ChatGPT 5 to translate the lyrics in Death by a Thousand Cuts, line by line, to see whether it would be able to provide a similar level of depth as the Swifties contributing to the song’s Genius lyric annotations.

title: Is ChatGPT a Swiftie?
section: An LLM’s analysis vs a fan’s obsession
text:
An LLM’s analysis vs a fan’s obsession

Intro
My, my, my, my

LLM: Repetition establishes a breathy, almost hypnotic opening — like someone taking stock of themselves. Sets a chanty, confessional mood.

My, my, my, my

LLM: (Repeat) Reinforces an internal, circular thought — the speaker is stuck in the same orbit of feeling.

My, my, my, my

LLM: (Repeat) The insistence creates tension: small words but big emotional weight.)

My, my, my, my

LLM: (Repeat) Feels like a mantra; musically it gives the singer space to play with phrasing and vulnerability.)

My, my, my, my

LLM: (Repeat) The continued echo suggests obsession or a looped memory — the beginning of processing loss.)

From Genius:

“This intro foreshadows the bridge of the song, on which Swift lists what she risked for the now-ex lover she speaks of. In addition, a popular fan theory ties this intro to the lyric “you’re my, my, my, my lover” from the album’s title track. Since this is a breakup song, Swift is no longer able to call this lover hers, so she frustratedly repeats “my,” hoping to find him again.”



Chorus
Saying goodbye is death by a thousand cuts

LLM: Central metaphor: breakups aren’t one big event but many small painful moments. Strong, memorable phrase that frames the whole song.

Flashbacks waking me up

LLM: Concrete image of intrusive memory; “waking” implies the memories invade both mind and sleep — physical and psychological pain.

I get drunk, but it’s not enough

LLM: Self-medication fails; drink is a classic temporary escape that can’t erase emotional injury — honest and relatable admission.

’Cause the morning comes and you’re not my baby

LLM: Morning as reality check — nighttime dulls the pain but daylight brings clarity (and loneliness). “Not my baby” is plain and gutting.

From Genius

In the Netflix film Someone Great, which serves as the inspiration for this song, the protagonist’s relationship with her ex-boyfriend is shown through flashbacks, brought on by seeing different reminders of her past. Throughout the movie, the protagonist periodically gets drunk and high, in an effort to deal with the pain of the failed relationship.



Bridge
My heart, my hips, my body, my love

LLM: Cataloging the parts of self involved — physical and emotional. The list is intimate and rhythmic, almost liturgical.

Tryna find a part of me that you didn’t touch

LLM: “Touched” functions both literally and metaphorically: intimacy and influence. Searching for untouched ground suggests violation or full absorption by the relationship.

Gave up on me like I was a bad drug

LLM: Sharp simile indicating discard and moral judgment; “bad drug” is addictive but ultimately harmful — shows betrayal and disposability.

Now I’m searching for signs in a haunted club

LLM: “Haunted club” is evocative: places tied to the relationship now feel ghostly. “Searching for signs” implies looking for meaning or clues to what went wrong.

Our songs, our films, united we stand

LLM: Lists cultural markers of togetherness — playlists and movie references are the small building blocks of coupleship.

Our country, guess it was a lawless land

LLM: Darkly witty pivot: what felt like shared sovereignty actually lacked rules that protected them — exaggerates breakdown of trust and order.

From Genius

This motif of physical touch–perhaps an allusion to sex–ties into the idea of a thousand cuts. With every touch, Swift’s partner cut her emotionally. Metaphors relating to bodies are common in Swift’s other songs. In “Cornelia Street,” the track immediately before this, Swift creates an extended metaphor about her partner holding cards, culminating in a symbolic phone call.

title: Is ChatGPT a Swiftie?
text:
Analysis & Takeaways
For reference, I sampled some of the most impactful parts of the song, rather than each line because it is quite long. By including parts of the intro, chorus, and bridge, I was able to get a well-rounded view between an LLM’s analysis of a song and a fan’s.
It is clear to me that an LLM simply does not have a fan’s touch. The obsession and internet sleuthing and references that a fan can build over time is not inherent to the LLM. GPT-5 instead focused on how the lyric may mean to society and does not place any personalized aspect in its descriptions.
Let the fans prevail,
Mallika

My biggest accomplishment to date has been winning first place at the 2025 Wharton Hack-AI-thon with my team’s project, Dyscover. The challenge asked us to create a tool that could revolutionize education, and we built an AI handwriting analysis model designed for early dyslexia detection. We integrated OpenAI’s API for generating personalized lesson plans, with predefined prompts for ease of use. Also, we used Gradio UI for intuitive teacher interaction—upload sample, receive confidence score.
In the weeks that followed, I was able to connect with leaders in the learning disability space, from the Chief of Data and AI at the United Nations International Computing Center to educational researchers at AIM Academy. title: "Lost in Translation 2"
description: "How far can language bend before it breaks? For a second time" 
author: "Mallika Kulkarni"

I used the same chained translation structure as before, again favoring the model by choosing commonly supported languages.
This time, I used the following chain:

title: Background
text:
Professional Script

Original Script
I appreciate your feedback, but I want to clarify that the final decision was made after careful consideration of all available data.


Translated to Japanese
ご意見ありがとうございますが、最終的な決定はすべての利用可能なデータを慎重に検討した上で行われたことをご理解ください。


Translated to French
Je vous remercie pour vos commentaires, mais je vous prie de comprendre que la décision finale a été prise après un examen attentif de toutes les données disponibles.


Translated back to English
Thank you for your comments, but please understand that the final decision was made after a careful review of all available data.
At first glance, this looks almost perfect. The meaning is preserved. The structure is intact. If you were grading this purely on semantic accuracy, you would give it full points.
But something subtle has changed.
The original sentence carries a slightly defensive tone. It politely pushes back while asserting authority. In professional English, “I want to clarify” often signals controlled disagreement. The translated version replaces this with “please understand,” which softens the assertiveness and reframes the sentence as explanatory rather than corrective.
This is not wrong. But it is different.
In a professional setting, that difference matters. The translated version sounds less like a boundary and more like reassurance. Over repeated interactions, that shift could change how the speaker is perceived in terms of confidence or authority.

title: Background
text:
Power Tone Script

Original Script
I’m happy to help, but moving forward, I’ll need clearer communication to avoid misunderstandings.
This sentence is doing a lot of work. It sounds friendly, but it is setting a boundary. The power comes from what is implied, not what is stated outright.


Translated to Japanese
お手伝いできて嬉しいですが、今後誤解を避けるためには、より明確なコミュニケーションが必要です。


Translated to French
Je suis heureux de vous aider, mais à l’avenir, une communication plus claire sera nécessaire afin d’éviter les malentendus.


Translated back to English
I am happy to help, but in the future, clearer communication will be necessary to avoid misunderstandings.

title: Background
text:
Takeaways
This experiment reinforces something important about using LLMs in multilingual settings. Translation accuracy is not the same as communicative accuracy. A sentence can be perfectly translated and still fail to do its job socially.
Over multiple translations, tone does not shatter dramatically. It erodes slowly. Authority becomes politeness. Boundaries become explanations. Directness becomes neutrality.
Thanks for getting lost in translation with me again, 翻訳に付き合ってくれてありがとう, Merci d’avoir traduit avec moi,
Mallika

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Background
How far can language bend before it breaks? Technically forever. Common consensus is that with language anything can be communicated, so meaning should be consistent among translation. Human sentiment can be one of the most important things with language and we must test whether an LLM can interpret that sentiment. Otherwise, it will fail with repeated translation.
I used some of the most commonly spoken languages in order to favor the GPT as much as possible. In this experiment, I ran several English paragraphs through a language chain using Claude because Anthropic has tested better for language skills:

English → Hindi → Spanish → back to English
My goal was to test prompt chaining across different types of text and see how meaning and nuance is interpreted by LLMs.

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Setup
For each test, I used GPT-4o and prompted it to do the following:
Translate the source paragraph from English to Hindi,

then translate that Hindi paragraph to Spanish,

then translate that Spanish back to English.
I conducted these translations separately, by copy and pasting into different prompting chats. This way GPT retained no knowledge between past prompt and did not just recall an earlier prompt. All translations were done separately, in sequence. I also want to be able to see this linguistic drift in 2 different contexts: a very casual conversation as well as a technical conversation. I predict that there will be less drift in a technical conversation because it will rely more on direct word translation.

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Technical Script

Original Script
A hash table provides average-case constant-time complexity for insertions and lookups, assuming a good hash function with minimal collisions.

Translated to Spanish
Una tabla hash proporciona complejidad de tiempo constante en caso promedio para inserción y búsqueda, siempre que tenga una buena función hash con colisiones mínimas.


Translated back to English
A hash table provides constant time complexity on average for insertion and search, as long as it has a good hash function with minimal collisions.

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Casual Script

Original Script
Okay but like… if you respond with ‘lol’ one more time, I’m gonna assume you actually hate me and you’re just being polite about it.


Translated to Hindi
“ठीक है लेकिन यार… अगर तुमने एक बार और ‘lol’ से जवाब दिया, तो मैं समझ जाऊंगा कि तुम सच में मुझसे नफरत करते हो और बस शिष्टाचार के लिए बात कर रहे हो।”


Translated to Spanish
“Está bien, pero hermano… si respondes con ‘lol’ una vez más, entenderé que realmente me odias y solo estás hablando por cortesía.”


Translated back to English
“It’s okay, but brother… if you respond with ‘lol’ one more time, I’ll understand that you really hate me and are only talking out of courtesy.”

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Takeaways
The hypothesis I posed at the beginning seems fairly accurate. The translation loop gets broken in the casual script because an LLM cannot capture the nuance of language and slang across multiple languages. However, I will note that an LLM performs comparably to Google Translate which is pretty industry leading in free text translation tools. GPT is a solid translator word-for-word, but context and nuance can get scrambled fast. Languages like Hindi and Spanich carry their own cultural assumptions and syntactic structures; LLMs don’t always account for that drift.
